ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A deeper understanding for the meaning of phase transitions and the analysis of their corresponding phenomena.
Advanced statistical physics, e.g. scaling laws, renormalization group, etc.
Finally understood RG a little bit

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: - Gives a qualitative and practical understanding of the Renormalization Group - Integrates computational techniques to understand how what is learned is implemented in modern research Weaknesses: - Mostly due to the instructors first time teaching this course, assignments often required revisions to be completed - After we finished using Goldenfeld, many students felt that there was little structure to go on. More homework assignments were needed here or a rigorous text needs to be utilized. This is characteristic of advanced physics courses, however, where literature is sparse and is often not tailored to the course needs.

strengths: it covers many interesting and important topic in advanced statistical physics, like scaling laws and renormalization group. to improve: it might be better if we can be more rigorous on derivation and explain things in more details, sometimes I could follow the lecture
I would have preferred more regular homework (e.g. one or two problems every week instead of larger, but sporadic, homework assignments).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class is essential for any theoretical physicist. It tackles fundamentals that are essential for a variety of fields.
I would recommend it to those who know little about topics covered in this course. This course may be an introduction to these topics.

Yes I would. I attempted this course previously, and it was much better the second time around. I think this course depends a lot on the professor who teaches it, and I think Prof. Machta's version is much more approachable.
